this model appears to be the older one, without the neck zipper
for now, we pretend this is what's been issued to soldiers most-recently
description: A thin shirt with long camouflaged sleeves and khaki body fabric that extends into a tiny collar; produced by Massif.  Made of a proprietary synthetic fabric that's breathable and flame-resistant, this model had been issued to Army soldiers as part of the standard uniform prior to the Cataclysm.  Designed primary for hot-weather conditions, it holds its own well in milder weather.  Has a small pocket on each sleeve, and two slots for pens on the left sleeve.
//weight: between three available sources of weight (each presumably for a different size), we take an average

thickness presumed

we're specifically using the temperate-weather model
description: Model C790 waterproof combat boots; produced by Belleville.  Approved for flight with both Army and Air Force, these became standard issue in temperate climates, with hot- and cold-climate variants also available.  These boots have solid grip on most terrain.
//weight: 31 oz per boot × 2 = 62 oz = 1757.7 g ≈ 1758 g

notes: dimensions acquired from visual reference
based on the model in source's photos

name.str_pl: pairs of Mechanix Wear Specialty tactical gloves

description: A pair of tactical gloves.  Relatively-thin and with numerous changes made to ensure maximum hand and trigger finger dexterity, the Specialty gloves are designed primarily for military and law-enforcement use.  The outer side of the glove is made of a breathable material, ensuring comfort during prolonged wear.  The inner side is made of faux leather, with the goal of improving firearm handling.

notes: length is 5.25 in. (finger length from source) + 40% (roughly the rest of the palm length)
first trim is to account for negative space between prism and fingers
second trim is to account for thumb (thumb is ~16-18% of the volume of the hand)

//material: leather stands in for AX Suede: a synthetic material with leather-like texture; a faux leather

//notes: modelled after size MR (medium, regular length), the unisex model
it isn't readily apparent that Propper is the sole or primary manufacturer of the coat
however, their blog mentions the company being “the largest supplier of US military uniforms„
https://www.propper.com/blog/new-acu
otherwise, the information on who manufactures the coat does not appear to be readily available online
we assume that Propper is indeed the sole or primary manufacturer, and refer to the company as such in the item's description
description: A thin coat covered in camouflage; produced by Propper.  Made from a ripstop material that combines nylon and cotton, this model had been issued to Army soldiers as part of the standard uniform prior to the Cataclysm.  Features two sleeve pockets, two chest pockets, and two slots for pens on the left sleeve.

notes: thickness presumed

//material: 50/50 mix of ripstop (nylon and cotton) complies with Army's NIR (near-infrared signature) requirements
//armor: the coat also has a small collar, but the game does not like neck coverage not being on the BELTED slot

description: A durable pair of pants covered in camouflage; manufactured by Propper.  Made from a ripstop material that combines nylon and cotton, this model had been issued to Army soldiers as part of the standard uniform prior to the Cataclysm.  Design features reinforced seat, felled seams, and leg closure via a drawstring.  Features two front pockets, two backpockets, two slanted cargo pockets, and two knee/ankle pockets.

notes: rise length is assumed to be between medium and high rise, which would provide a good balance between strictness of the uniform and wearer comfort
trim accounts for a possible gap between pant legs when the pants are laid out flat

//snippet_category.text: A tough pair of pants.  Favored by the military.  This pair sports the US Army's gray, green and tan Universal Camouflage Pattern.  The pattern is notable for its lack of black.
A tough pair of military pants patterned in desert camouflage.  They are lined with deep pockets.
A tough pair of military pants with a black, green and tan pixel camouflage pattern.  Commonly seen worn by US Marines.
A tough pair of military pants with the black, brown, green and tan Battle Dress camouflage pattern.  They look old.
A tough pair of military pants with a predominantly dark blue camouflage.  Favored by the US Navy.

//notes: modelled after size MR (medium, regular length)
most properties copied from the Wild Things jacket
research suggests that sleeve pockets are universal between different items of clothing

name.str: ECWCS Gen III Level V soft-shell jacket

description: A lightweight, comfortable soft-shell jacket; manufactured by Tennier Industries.  This jacket is part of the third generation of the ECWCS (Extended Cold Weather Clothing System): a layered-clothing system employed by the U.S. Army, designed to protect soldiers from extreme-cold and/or wet conditions.  The jacket features two sleeve pockets and two chest pockets; you can keep your hands warm in the chest pockets.  It also has a hood that folds into the collar, as well as armpit zippers for managing heat and moisture ventilation.

notes: chest length doubled for circumference
thickness presumed based on the fact that it's meant to be part of a layered cold-weather system
trim is to account for the volume of the hood

//material_thickness: half the assumed overall thickness of the jacket
//warmth: non-insulated, intended to be worn with ECWCS underlayer

notes: length is calculated as length of Velcro patch (6 in.) + offset from top/bottom (0.0625 in.) * 2
height is assumed from visual reference as maximum possible vertical stretch of the pocket
trim is to account for the tapering of the pocket

height is assumed from visual reference as maximum possible vertical stretch of the pocket
trim is to account for the tapering of the pocket

research suggests that cargo pockets are universal between different items of clothing

this means we have to use the weight of the trouser with suspenders as weight of just the trouser

name.str_sp: ECWCS Gen III Level V soft-shell trouser

description: A lightweight, comfortable soft-shell set of pants; manufactured by Tennier Industries.  These pants are a part of the third generation of the ECWCS (Extended Cold Weather Clothing System): a layered-clothing system employed by the U.S. Army, designed to protect soldiers from extreme-cold and/or wet conditions.  The pants feature two front pockets and two cargo pockets; you can keep your hands warm in the front pockets.  Its elastic waistband and hems prevent heat from leaving when managing colder temperatures.

notes: rise length is assumed to be between medium and high rise, which would provide a good balance between strictness of the uniform and wearer comfort
trim accounts for a possible gap between pant legs when the pants are laid out flat

//warmth: non-insulated, intended to be worn with ECWCS underlayer
//pocket_data: we assume the pockets are the same as those of the ACU combat trouser
except for back pockets, which this item doesn't seem to have

//notes: modelled after men's size M
Outdoor Research is the U.S. Army supplier
https://fragoutmag.com/outdoor-research-awarded-us-army-cold-weather-glove-system-cwgs-contract/
description: A pair of thick, insulated mitts with a separate trigger finger; manufactured by Outdoor Research, and sold commercially as Firebrand TF Mitts.  Part of CWGS (Cold Weather Glove System), this pair of mitts was commissioned by the U.S. Army to enable combat in conditions of extreme cold.  Resistive leather over the trigger finger enables the use of touch screens without taking the mitt off.

notes: length is 6.25 in. (average length of men's size M/8 glove), doubled to account for the sleeve
width is circumference (for men's size M/8 glove) divided by 2 (one side)
first trim is to account for negative space between prism and fingers
second trim is to account the sleeve being significantly thinner
third trim is to account for thumb (thumb is ~16-18% of the volume of the hand)

//material: leather in these gloves comes in two variaties: goat leather and touchscreen leather
wool stands in for PrimaLoft insulation

armor.//encumbrance: separate trigger finger gives it a slight advantage in terms of encumbrance

description: A pair of thin, warm gloves; manufactured by Outdoor Research.  Intended to be used as an underlayer for a heavier, thicker pair of gloves, these can also be used on their own.  Part of CWGS (Cold Weather Glove System), this pair of lines was commissioned by the U.S. Army to enable combat in conditions of extreme cold.  Resistive leather over the index finger and the thumb enables the use of touch screens without taking the liner off.

notes: length is 6.25 in. (average length of men's size M/8 glove) + 80%
width is circumference (for men's size M/8 glove) divided by 2 (one side)
first trim is to account for negative space between prism and fingers
second trim is to account for thumb (thumb is ~16-18% of the volume of the hand)

//material: also a tiny piece of conductive leather at the fingertips
